Migration Linter
All notable changes to Laravel Migration Linter are documented here.
Laravel Migration Linter integrates seamlessly with GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, and other continuous integration pipelines.
The Laravel Migration Linter ships with a configurable file that defines which rules are active and how severe their findings should be.
Install Laravel Migration Linter via Composer:
Each rule can be enabled, disabled, or adjusted for severity in config/migration-linter.php.
After installing the package, run the linter on all migrations:
Laravel Migration Linter is designed to be fully extensible â€”
Laravel,  migrations,  linter,  PHP,  CI/CD,  database,  schema,  sufyandev
Laravel,  migrations,  linter,  PHP,  CI/CD,  database,  schema,  sufyandev
Laravel,  migrations,  linter,  PHP,  CI/CD,  database,  schema,  sufyandev

Laravel,  migrations,  linter,  PHP,  CI/CD,  database,  schema,  sufyandev
Laravel,  migrations,  linter,  PHP,  CI/CD,  database,  schema,  sufyandev
Laravel,  migrations,  linter,  PHP,  CI/CD,  database,  schema,  sufyandev
â€œSmart developers donâ€™t debug production â€” they lint migrations.â€

Laravel Migration Linter is a lightweight developer tool that automatically scans your database migrations for risky schema changes before they hit production. It acts as a static analyzer for your migrations â€” preventing downtime, data loss, or broken deploys by catching unsafe patterns early in your CI/CD pipeline.

ðŸ§  Safety-first linting â€” Detects dangerous operations like adding non-nullable columns without defaults or dropping columns. âš¡ Performance awareness â€” Warns when missing indexes or inefficient data types can impact query speed. ðŸ’¾ Data integrity checks â€” Alerts when unique constraints, float columns, or type changes may corrupt data. ðŸ§© Configurable rules â€” Enable, disable, or adjust severity (info, warning, error) per project. ðŸ§± Baseline support â€” Ignore known legacy issues and focus only on new violations. ðŸ“Š Developer-friendly reports â€” Colorized console output, JSON export, and compact mode. ðŸ¤– CI/CD ready â€” Integrates cleanly with GitHub Actions, GitLab, and other pipelines.

Traditional Laravel migrations execute directly on production data â€” even small mistakes can cause downtime. Laravel Migration Linter analyzes migrations before they run, letting you: Prevent table locks and schema conflicts Detect destructive operations in pull requests Enforce safe migration practices across teams Standardize schema evolution in CI/CD workflows

Screenshot from v1.0.0 â€” showing lint warnings with flag check_all_tables => false in console output Screenshot from v1.1.1 â€” showing lint warnings with flag check_all_tables => true in console output

ðŸ“¦ Installation Guide â€” Learn how to install and publish config ðŸ§© Usage â€” See command options and examples âš™ï¸ Configuration â€” Customize rule severities ðŸ§  Writing Custom Rules â€” Create your own organization-specific checks ðŸ¤– CI/CD Integration â€” Enforce linting in automated pipelines Â© 2025 Sufyan â€” Released under the MIT License.
All notable changes to Laravel Migration Linter are documented here. This project follows Semantic Versioning.

Core Artisan command: php artisan migrate:lint Base rules: AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault MissingIndexOnForeignKey Config publishing (php artisan vendor:publish --tag="migration-linter-config") Baseline file support (--generate-baseline, --baseline=path) JSON output mode (--json) Compact report output for smaller terminals.

DropColumnWithoutBackup rule â€” warns when columns are dropped without confirmation or backup. AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn rule â€” warns when adding unique constraints that might fail on existing data. FloatColumnForMoney rule â€” warns when using float() for monetary fields; recommends decimal(10,2) instead.
Enhanced output formatting for compact mode (--compact) on smaller terminals. Configuration system now supports custom rules from any namespace (e.g., App\MigrationRules).
Added rule discovery improvements in RuleEngine. Documentation updates (rules.md, writing-custom-rules.md, and configuration.md).
Initial public release with baseline rule set: AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault MissingIndexOnForeignKey DropColumnWithoutBackup AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn FloatColumnForMoney

AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault Detects .change() on existing columns. Skips Schema::create() (safe for new tables). MissingIndexOnForeignKey Detects foreignId() without ->constrained(). Detects morphs() / nullableMorphs() without ->index(). Detects composite foreign([...]) without matching index([...]). DropColumnWithoutBackup Detects multiple column drops. Supports safe comment whitelist (// safe drop or /* safe-drop */). AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn Detects composite unique constraints. Detects inline ->unique() and ->unique()->change(). Configurable check_composite flag. FloatColumnForMoney Detects float(), double(), and real() for money-like columns. Smarter pattern matching (price, amount, total, tax, etc.). Configurable toggles: check_double and check_real.
Unified severity handling via config. More informative lint messages for each rule. Added full Pest test coverage for all five rules. Enhanced documentation and configuration examples.

Config overrides now correctly respect enabled = false. RuleEngine dynamically skips disabled rules during lint runs. Reporter tests aligned with real Laravel OutputStyle. ðŸ§  Tip: You can always check your installed version via Composer: composer show sufyandev/laravel-migration-linter Or compare changes on GitHub: ðŸ‘‰ muhammad-sufyan5/sufyan-laravel-migration-lint-package

Laravel Migration Linter integrates seamlessly with GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, and other continuous integration pipelines. It ensures no unsafe schema changes reach production by failing builds when risky migrations are detected.

name: Laravel Migration Linter on: push: branches: [ main, master ] pull_request: branches: [ main, master ] jobs: lint-migrations: runs-on: ubuntu-latest steps: - uses: actions/checkout@v4 - uses: shivammathur/setup-php@v2 with: php-version: 8.3 extensions: mbstring, pdo, bcmath, curl, dom, xml tools: composer:v2 # ðŸ§© Example: setting up a test Laravel project using your local package - run: composer create-project laravel/laravel test-laravel-app --quiet - name: Install Laravel Migration Linter (local path) run: | cd test-laravel-app composer config repositories.sufyandev path ../ composer require sufyandev/laravel-migration-linter:@dev --no-interaction - name: Run Migration Linter run: | cd test-laravel-app php artisan migrate:lint --json > lint-report.json

Severity Threshold Description Exit Code Build Result info Advisory messages only 0 âœ… Pass warning Potential issues found, not fatal 0 âœ… Pass error Migration-breaking or data-loss risks 1 âŒ Fail You can adjust this threshold via config/migration-linter.php: 'severity_threshold' => 'error', When set to 'error', only error-level issues cause your CI pipeline to fail.
documents.s: ðŸ“Š Exit Codes and Build Behavior

documents.t: ðŸ’¾ Commit the baseline file (migration-linter-baseline.json) once generated. This prevents known legacy issues from reappearing in reports. ðŸ§© Use --json output to generate structured reports for custom dashboards. You can also upload the JSON artifact for analysis. ðŸš¦ Fail fast: set 'severity_threshold' => 'error' in config to stop deployments on risky migrations. ðŸ” Run on every PR â€” this ensures every migration is linted before merge.

If you're using GitLab, add a stage like this: stages: - lint lint_migrations: stage: lint image: php:8.3 script: - apt-get update && apt-get install -y unzip git - curl -sS https://getcomposer.org/installer | php - php composer.phar install --no-interaction - php artisan migrate:lint --json > lint-report.json âœ… Result: Your CI/CD pipeline now automatically enforces safe, production-ready migrations â€” blocking schema-breaking changes before they reach your main branch.

The Laravel Migration Linter ships with a configurable file that defines which rules are active and how severe their findings should be. You can customize this file to match your team's migration safety standards.
If you havenâ€™t already, publish the configuration file to your app: php artisan vendor:publish --tag="migration-linter-config" This creates: config/migration-linter.php

return [ /* |-------------------------------------------------------------------------- | Severity Threshold |-------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | This controls the exit code behavior of the linter. | - If set to "error", the command will exit with 1 whenever an "error" rule triggers. | - If set to "warning", only "warning" or higher severities are reported. | */ 'severity_threshold' => 'warning', /* |-------------------------------------------------------------------------- | Rules |-------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Enable, disable, or adjust severity for any built-in or custom rules. | You can also register your own rules by adding their class name or short key. | */ 'rules' => [ 'AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', ], 'MissingIndexOnForeignKey' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', ], 'DropColumnWithoutBackup' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', ], 'AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', ], 'FloatColumnForMoney' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', ], // Example custom rule (auto-discovered from App\MigrationRules) 'NoUnsignedBigIntRule' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', ], ], ];

Level Meaning Exit Code Recommended Usage info Advisory only; does not affect CI 0 Local hints or code-style warnings warning Possible performance or safety issue 0 Default level for most rules error Migration-breaking or data-loss risk 1 Use in CI/CD pipelines to block risky merges

You can disable a rule entirely by setting 'enabled' => false. To treat warnings as failures, change the global threshold to 'error'. Custom rules defined in App\MigrationRules or any namespaced class are automatically discovered â€” no code changes needed in the package. See ðŸ§  Writing Custom Rules for detailed examples of defining your own rules. âœ… Pro Tip: Commit your config/migration-linter.php file to version control so your whole team shares the same linting standards.

Install Laravel Migration Linter via Composer: composer require sufyandev/laravel-migration-linter --dev ðŸ’¡ Itâ€™s recommended to install it as a development dependency since itâ€™s used primarily during code review and CI, not in production runtime.

The package will auto-register through Laravelâ€™s package discovery, so no manual provider entry is required. After installation, youâ€™re ready to lint your migrations immediately. If you prefer, you can verify the service provider is loaded: php artisan list | grep lint You should see: migrate:lint Statistically analyze migration files for risky schema changes

If youâ€™d like to customize rule severities or enable/disable specific rules: php artisan vendor:publish --tag="migration-linter-config" This will create: config/migration-linter.php You can then adjust individual rules or add your own custom ones (see ðŸ§  Writing Custom Rules).

Use the built-in Artisan command to analyze your migrations: php artisan migrate:lint Example output: ðŸ” Running Laravel Migration Linter... âš ï¸ Lint Report [warning] AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault â†’ Column 'email' on table 'users' is non-nullable without a default value.

ðŸ§© Usage â€” See command options and examples âš™ï¸ Configuration â€” Customize rule severities ðŸ§  Writing Custom Rules â€” Create your own organization-specific checks ðŸ¤– CI/CD Integration â€” Enforce linting in automated pipelines

Each rule can be enabled, disabled, or adjusted for severity in config/migration-linter.php. Laravel Migration Linter analyzes your migration files and flags potential schema risks. Below are the built-in linting rules, each with rationale, triggers, and configuration examples.

Severity Meaning Typical Use info Advisory only Local development warning Risk detected, migration may succeed but unsafe Default error Definite risk, migration should fail in CI Production enforcement
AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault MissingIndexOnForeignKey DropColumnWithoutBackup AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn FloatColumnForMoney
Category: Reliability / Safety Default severity: warning

Warns when a NOT NULL column is added to an existing table without a default value. On a table that already contains data, adding or altering a non-nullable column requires a default or a backfill step; otherwise the migration may fail or cause long-running locks. The rule now also detects: ->change() calls that modify existing columns to NOT NULL. Automatically skips Schema::create() migrations (new tables). Honors config keys large_table_names and check_all_tables.

MySQL and PostgreSQL will try to fill existing rows with NULL, violating the NOT NULL constraint. Large tables can experience long locks while the new column is materialized. Production deploys may fail midway, leaving partially applied migrations.

$table->string('email')->nullable(false); $table->integer('quantity')->nullable(false); âœ… Safe alternatives // Option 1: Provide a sensible default $table->string('email')->default('')->nullable(false); // Option 2: Add as nullable, backfill, then alter $table->string('email')->nullable(); DB::table('users')->update(['email' => '']); $table->string('email')->nullable(false)->change(); âš™ï¸ Configuration 'AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', // change to 'error' to fail CI ], Additional global options: 'large_table_names' => ['users', 'orders'], // Only check these if check_all_tables = false 'check_all_tables' => true, // Lint all tables by default ðŸ§¾ Example output [warning] AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault â†’ Column 'email' on table 'users' is non-nullable without a default value.

Always provide a default value when adding NOT NULL columns. When modifying existing columns, use a two-step migration: Add or backfill data. Then enforce the NOT NULL constraint. Skip new-table checks since Schema::create() is safe.
Category: Performance / Integrity Default severity: warning

Warns when foreign keyâ€“like columns are added without an index or foreign-key constraint. The rule now detects: foreignId('user_id') without ->constrained() morphs() or nullableMorphs() without ->index() Composite foreign([...]) keys without an accompanying index([...]) (Legacy _id heuristic removed for better accuracy)

Queries that join on the foreign-key column become slow without an index. Deletes or updates on the parent table can lock the child table. Missing indexes lead to poor query-planner choices and high I/O cost. Composite keys without indexes can lead to full-table scans.

// ðŸš« No ->constrained() â€” adds column but not FK or index $table->foreignId('user_id'); // ðŸš« No ->index() on polymorphic relation $table->morphs('taggable'); // ðŸš« Composite foreign key without index $table->foreign(['user_id', 'tenant_id']) ->references(['id', 'id']) ->on('users'); âœ… Safe alternatives // âœ… add explicit constraint $table->foreignId('user_id')->constrained(); // âœ… add index to polymorphic relation $table->morphs('taggable'); $table->index(['taggable_id', 'taggable_type']); // âœ… composite FK with matching index $table->foreign(['user_id', 'tenant_id']) ->references(['id', 'id']) ->on('users'); $table->index(['user_id', 'tenant_id']); âš™ï¸ Configuration 'MissingIndexOnForeignKey' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', // or 'error' to block CI // ðŸ§© Feature toggles 'check_foreign_id_without_constrained' => true, 'check_morphs_without_index' => true, 'check_composite_foreign' => true, ], ðŸ§¾ Example output [warning] MissingIndexOnForeignKey â†’ Column 'user_id' on table 'orders' uses foreignId() but has no ->constrained(); constraint or index may be missing. [warning] MissingIndexOnForeignKey â†’ Polymorphic relation 'taggable' on table 'tags' has no index; consider adding ->index() for faster lookups.

Always use instead of manual unsignedBigInteger(). Index all polymorphic relations (morphs, nullableMorphs). Add composite indexes for multi-column foreign keys. Keep this rule enabled in CI to prevent slow queries and orphaned data.
Category: Data Safety Default severity: warning (consider setting to error in CI)

Warns whenever a migration drops one or more columns from a table without any indication of backup or confirmation. The rule now also: Detects multiple-column drops such as dropColumn(['a','b']). Skips warnings if the migration line includes a â€œsafe-dropâ€ comment, e.g. // safe drop or /* safe-drop */.

Dropping a column permanently deletes data â€” no rollback can recover it. Production databases often require a backup or rename step before deletion. Irreversible drops can break reports, analytics, or legacy code paths.

// ðŸš« Single column drop $table->dropColumn('middle_name'); // ðŸš« Multiple column drop $table->dropColumn(['middle_name', 'nickname']); âœ… Safer approaches // âœ… 1. Rename instead of drop (keep data) $table->renameColumn('middle_name', 'middle_name_old'); // âœ… 2. Back up before dropping DB::table('users') ->select('id', 'middle_name') ->whereNotNull('middle_name') ->chunk(500, fn ($rows) => Storage::disk('backups')->append('user_middle_names.csv', json_encode($rows)) ); // âœ… 3. Confirm safe drop explicitly $table->dropColumn(['middle_name', 'nickname']); // safe drop âš™ï¸ Configuration 'DropColumnWithoutBackup' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', // can be 'error' in strict mode 'allow_safe_comment' => true, // skip warnings for "// safe drop" comments ], ðŸ§¾ Example output [warning] DropColumnWithoutBackup â†’ Dropping multiple columns ('middle_name', 'nickname') from table 'users' may result in data loss.

Treat column drops as production-critical operations. Always back up or rename before deletion. Use // safe drop comments to explicitly acknowledge intentional removals. In CI, set severity = error to prevent accidental data loss migrations.
Category: Data Integrity Default severity: warning

Warns when a migration adds a unique constraint (either explicitly or inline) to a column that may already contain duplicate data. The rule now detects: Explicit $table->unique('column') Composite $table->unique(['col1','col2']) Inline ->unique() calls on column definitions Inline ->unique()->change() calls that modify existing columns Optional config flag to disable composite detection

If duplicates exist, the migration will fail and may roll back partially. Even if it succeeds on empty tables, applying later on filled tables can break deploys. Large tables with duplicates can cause long locks during constraint creation.

// ðŸš« explicit unique constraint $table->unique('email'); // ðŸš« composite unique constraint $table->unique(['email', 'tenant_id']); // ðŸš« inline unique definition $table->string('email')->unique(); // ðŸš« inline unique with change() on existing column $table->string('username')->unique()->change(); âœ… Safer rollout pattern // 1ï¸âƒ£ Detect duplicates $dupes = DB::table('users') ->select('email') ->groupBy('email') ->havingRaw('COUNT(*) > 1') ->get(); if ($dupes->isNotEmpty()) { // cleanup manually or via script before migration } // 2ï¸âƒ£ Once deduped, safely add constraint $table->unique('email'); âš™ï¸ Configuration 'AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', // can raise to 'error' for CI enforcement 'check_composite' => true, // enable composite unique detection ], ðŸ§¾ Example output [warning] AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn â†’ Adding composite unique constraint on ('email', 'tenant_id') in 'users' may fail if duplicates already exist.

Always scan for duplicates before adding unique constraints. Use two-step rollouts for production: detect + cleanup, then constrain. Avoid adding uniqueness inline during schema creation on large tables. Disable check_composite if composite indexes are validated elsewhere.
Category: Precision / Data Integrity Default severity: warning

Warns when a migration defines a float column for values that appear to represent money or currency (e.g., price, amount, balance, total, etc.). The rule now detects: float(), double(), or real() methods used on money-like columns. Column names containing terms such as _price, _amount, _cost, _balance, _tax, _fee, _total, _revenue, _discount, _charge, _credit, etc. Configurable detection for double() and real() usage.

Floating-point numbers introduce rounding errors that can silently corrupt financial totals. Different database engines may round differently (especially MySQL vs. PostgreSQL). Financial, billing, and accounting tables require exact precision â€” use decimal(p, s) instead.

// ðŸš« Inaccurate monetary representation $table->float('price'); $table->double('amount'); $table->real('balance'); $table->float('tax'); $table->float('total'); âœ… Recommended alternatives // âœ… Use fixed-point decimal type with precision and scale $table->decimal('price', 10, 2); $table->decimal('amount', 12, 4); // âœ… For safety, define a custom schema macro $table->money('price'); // wraps decimal(10, 2) âš™ï¸ Configuration 'FloatColumnForMoney' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', // can be 'error' for strict CI mode 'check_double' => true, // include double() in checks 'check_real' => true, // include real() in checks ], ðŸ§¾ Example output [warning] FloatColumnForMoney â†’ Column 'amount' in table 'payments' uses double(); consider using decimal(10,2) or storing values in minor units (e.g. cents).

Use decimal(p, s) (commonly decimal(10,2) or decimal(12,4)) for any money, cost, tax, or balance fields. Reserve float(), double(), or real() for scientific or approximate data (measurements, ratios, etc.). Avoid floating-point math in any table representing financial accuracy or audits.
After installing the package, run the linter on all migrations: php artisan migrate:lint This scans your database/migrations folder for risky schema operations and reports potential issues.

You can customize the linting behavior using the following flags and options: Option / Flag Description --generate-baseline Create a baseline JSON file (migration-linter-baseline.json) that records current issues, allowing you to ignore them in future runs (useful when introducing the linter to legacy projects). --path= Lint a specific file or directory instead of the default database/migrations folder. --json Output results in structured JSON format (ideal for CI/CD or automation). --baseline= Provide a custom path to a baseline file (overrides the default baseline file). --compact Display a shorter, condensed table layout for smaller terminals or narrow CI logs. --rules View all rules and their enabled statuses.
php artisan migrate:lint
php artisan migrate:lint --generate-baseline This creates migration-linter-baseline.json in your project root.
documents.s: ðŸ§¾ Generate a new baseline file (ignore current issues)

documents.t: php artisan migrate:lint --path=database/migrations/2025_10_20_123456_create_users_table.php

php artisan migrate:lint --json > storage/lint-report.json Example output (simplified): [ { "ruleId": "DropColumnWithoutBackup", "severity": "warning", "message": "Dropping column 'age' from table 'users' may result in data loss.", "file": "2025_10_20_123456_update_users_table.php" } ]
documents.s: ðŸ§  Export report as JSON (for CI pipelines)

documents.t: php artisan migrate:lint --baseline=storage/custom-baseline.json
documents.s: ðŸ—‚ Use a custom baseline file

documents.t: php artisan migrate:lint --rules Example output: ðŸ“‹ Available Migration Linter Rules +--------------------------------------------+----------+---------------------------------------------------------------+ | Rule ID | Enabled | Description | +--------------------------------------------+----------+---------------------------------------------------------------+ | AddNonNullableColumnWithoutDefault | Yes | Warns when adding a NOT NULL column without a default value. | | MissingIndexOnForeignKey | No | Detects missing indexes on foreign key columns. | | DropColumnWithoutBackup | Yes | Warns when columns are dropped without backup. | | AddUniqueConstraintOnNonEmptyColumn | No | Warns when adding unique constraints on existing data. | | FloatColumnForMoney | Yes | Warns when float() used for monetary values. | +--------------------------------------------+----------+---------------------------------------------------------------+
documents.s: ðŸ—‚ List all rules with their enabled statuses

documents.t: php artisan migrate:lint --compact This outputs a shorter version of the table without verbose file paths.
documents.s: ðŸ–¥ Compact mode for smaller terminals

documents.t: Exit Code Meaning When it occurs 0 âœ… No critical issues (or only warnings below threshold) Safe to proceed 1 âŒ One or more rules exceeded the severity threshold CI/CD should fail The threshold is controlled by severity_threshold in your configuration file. For example, setting 'severity_threshold' => 'error' will fail the command only when error-level issues are found.

Use --generate-baseline once when introducing the linter to a legacy codebase, then commit the baseline file. Regularly re-run php artisan migrate:lint in your CI/CD to catch unsafe schema changes early. Combine with your existing testing jobs to prevent migration issues from reaching production. âœ… Thatâ€™s it! Youâ€™re ready to lint, baseline, and enforce migration safety across all environments.
Laravel Migration Linter is designed to be fully extensible â€” you can easily create your own rule classes to lint for specific schema patterns or organization-specific policies.

Create a new rule class anywhere in your app or within a separate package. Each rule must extend the core Sufyan\MigrationLinter\Rules\AbstractRule class and implement: id() â†’ unique identifier (string) description() â†’ short explanation of what the rule checks check(Operation $operation) â†’ main logic (returns an array of Issue objects) Example: <?php namespace App\MigrationRules; use Sufyan\MigrationLinter\Rules\AbstractRule; use Sufyan\MigrationLinter\Support\Operation; class NoUnsignedBigIntRule extends AbstractRule { public function id(): string { return 'NoUnsignedBigIntRule'; } public function defaultSeverity(): string { return 'warning'; } public function description(): string { return 'Discourages the use of unsignedBigInteger for portability reasons.'; } /** * @return \Sufyan\MigrationLinter\Support\Issue[] */ public function check(Operation $operation): array { // Inspect the migration operation if ($operation->method === 'unsignedBigInteger') { return [ $this->warn( $operation, "Avoid using unsignedBigInteger on table '{$operation->table}'. Use bigInteger() instead for better portability." ), ]; } return []; } }
documents.s: ðŸ§© 1ï¸âƒ£ Create a Custom Rule Class

documents.t: Once your rule is ready, add it to the configuration file: // config/migration-linter.php return [ 'rules' => [ // Existing built-in rules... 'NoUnsignedBigIntRule' => [ 'enabled' => true, 'severity' => 'warning', // can be 'error' for strict enforcement ], ], ]; You can also publish the config file using: php artisan vendor:publish --tag="migration-linter-config"
Simply run: php artisan migrate:lint Your custom rule will now be executed alongside the built-in ones. If it finds any violations, theyâ€™ll appear in the standard lint report.

Use warn(), error(), or other helpers to create issues that respect severity from the config. Keep rules focused â€” each rule should detect one kind of problem clearly. Leverage Operation properties like: $operation->method â†’ migration method (e.g. string, dropColumn) $operation->args â†’ raw arguments as string $operation->table â†’ table name $operation->file â†’ file path Return an empty array if no issue is detected. You can group your own rules in a namespace like App\MigrationRules or App\LinterRules. ðŸ§  Example Output [warning] NoUnsignedBigIntRule â†’ Avoid using unsignedBigInteger on table 'users'. Use bigInteger() instead for better portability. âœ… Thatâ€™s it! Your custom rules will now integrate seamlessly with Laravel Migration Linterâ€™s reporting, severity configuration, and CI workflows.
